title: Before 4 January 2023, will a United States Supreme Court seat be vacated?
possible_answers: Yes, and a replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before 4 January 2023
Yes, but no replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before 4 January 2023
correct_answer: Yes, and a replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before 4 January 2023
preds: unless something crazy happens - with Susan Collins declaring she would vote for nominated Associate Justice KBJ - this should occur in the next couple of weeks
Manchin said he would vote to confirm Jackson.

Short of a major scandal (VERY unlikely with this nominee), I remain convinced confirmation will occur before 4 Jan 2023.  It is just March 2022, and the confirmation hearings start Monday and most signals I am tracking indicate a smooth confirmation.  Keeping my 99%.  Here are some of those signals: https://www.governing.com/context/myths-of-the-u-s-supreme-court; https://www.senate.gov/committees/hearings_meetings.htm; Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson; https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/interactive/2022/ketanji-brown-jackson-school-career/;

Judge Brown has already been pretty well-vetted. The odds that she is not confirmed depend on a Dem Senator flopping over dead or incapacitated in a state where they cannot be replaced with a Democrat. Not impossible, but slim.

Yes. Breyer retires in June and a replacement will be needed. I find it unimaginable that someone (even if it is not Ketanji Brown Jackson) has not been confirmed by January, it seems like too long to leave the seat open. Instinctually I wanted to go 99% to 1% to hedge a bit in case of some 'Hail Mary' attempt by the Republicans to permanently shrink the size of the court. But with Breyer already being associated with the liberal wing of the court it seems like a bad precedent to set over a seat that doesn't even shift the balance of the court. This seems as close to 100% as I can think.

Now that Jackson has been officially named as the nominee (as I anticipated in my forecast from January [1]) , I think the chance of a surprise event derailing the process has fallen to about 1 in 50 and is mostly related to unlikely potential issues with a few key Democratic Senators not falling critically ill / having scandals that lead to them exiting the Senate which I described in my February 2nd forecast [2]. I saw the story about Sentor Luján's stroke as per @Deerslayer 's comment [1] and realized I'd been substituting a hard question with an easy question. This is not just a matter of whether the Democratically controlled Senate will confirm Biden's nominee. The slim majority needs to remain intact until somewhere around early August to complete the confirmation. Although Luján is expected to recover and even if he had left the senate, he would have been replaced in time with another Democratic Senator, there are probably some Senators who, if they left, the governor of the state could conceivably slow walk the process of replacing them or replace them with someone who would not confirm Biden's nominee. I made a quick guess as to a potential list of Democratic Senators whose departure could be problematic (and please let me know if you think the list should be different). Here is the list: senators = {
    'Mark Kelley':['M',57],
    'Krysten Sinema':['F',45],
    'Maggie Hassan':['M',63],
    'Jeanne Shaheen':['F',75],
    'Jon Ossoff':['M',34],
    'Raphael Warnock':['M',52],
    'Tim Kaine':['M',63],
    'Mark Warner':['M',67],
    'Jon Tester':['M',65],
    'Sherrod Brown':['M',69],
    'Joe Manchin':['M',74],
    } As with my SCOTUS opening model [2], I used the mortality rates which I believe is reasonable, since even though I believe these Senators are less likely to die than others of the same age, they might need to leave for purposes of health or scandal, so it's reasonable for a ballpark estimate. I created a script [3] to estimate the probability that none of the Democratic Senators I listed will leave the Senate before the new SCOTUS confirmation and came up with about 93%.  Within that remaining 7%, how often is / are the leaving Senator(s) replaced with someone who would approve the nominee? How often would a few Republicans go along with the confirmation? If it happened early enough, would Breyer change his mind and not retire? I inclined to believe that enough Republicans would vote for Biden's nominee that it won't be an issue, but I'd be open to changing my mind. In the meantime, I'm going to move closer to the crowd forecast. @probahilliby  - I think you're not unreasonable to be at 1% for no. I'm at just under half a percent.
@belikewater - What do you think? Are you going to revise down as well? [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1391244
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1388398
[3] https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/scotus_opening/scotus_confirmation.py

There are two names being floated as the likely nominee: https://www.scotusblog.com/2022/01/how-biden-will-choose-the-next-supreme-court-nominee/
Odds are that the Administration has already done some of its homework in vetting the two candidates (given that Biden promised this nomination as part of his campaign speeches), and at least one was put into her current position with some level of bipartisan support. The Republicans removed the filibuster on Supreme Court nominees in order to push through Trump's nominations, so that is unlikely to be a factor for this nomination (unless Manchin or Sinema see some benefit in being a roadblock). Also, any Biden nomination wouldn't change the Court's current super majority of conservatives, so in theory wouldn't be worth Mitch McConnel falling on any swords to avoid: in fact, Republicans could cast themselves as conciliatory and reasonable by not putting up roadblocks since the appointment is really only symbolic and wouldn't lead to different court rulings (at least near term). On the other hand, Republicans could use opposition as a way to shore their base ahead of the November 2022 mid-terms and could put a number of tricks in play to stall things after the nomination is announced. So it's not a slam dunk.

Building on the modeling from my previous forecast [1], I've updated the script [2] to take in an estimated planned retirement probability for Justice Breyer (which I estimate is appoximately 1/3) and then combine it with my estimated probabilities of an unplanned vacancy within the supreme court justices which I described in my previous forecast. Since the probabilities are multiplied together to get the estimate, the order doesn't matter, but, logically, it is important to conceptualize that Breyer's planned retirement would reduce the chances of his unplanned vacancy and his unplanned vacancy would reduce the chances of his planned retirement, so this is accounted for. Furthermore, I apply a scalar to account for the time left until the expiration of the question where the probability of a vacancy gets lower and lower as the deadline approaches. That covers modeling the "No" probability. For the next iteration, I'll model the two buckets of the "Yes" probability, but for now I'll say that I think the chances are high that a replacement justice would be confirmed if there is an opening and sufficient time.
[1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1386167
[2] https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/tree/master/scotus_opening

This was an interesting study on SCOTUS retirement/death in office: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3000028/

Justice Breyer is currently 83 year old. For the purposes of base rate I am considering all justices who 1) served at least one day on the Supreme Court between January 1990 and January 2021, 2) left the bench either by death or retirement, and 3) were/are greater than 80 years in age.  20 justices have served on the court during this period. Subtracting the 9 currently serving justices (including Breyer, since he is the subject of the question), there are 11 justices who left the bench. 8 justices retired and 3 justices died while on the bench.  Of the 8 who retired, two (2) of them were younger than 80 years old, meaning the number of justices who fit the three criteria above is 9 (6 retired, 3 died).  Since January 1990:
3 of 9 died on the bench = 33%
6 of 9 retired voluntarily = 66%
I don't have access to Justice Breyer's health information and cannot assume he is at risk of death (any more than the rest of us) in the next year, so the base rate that he will vacate the seat by retirement is 66%.  Augmenting information: 
Of the 8 total justices who retired (referenced above - including the young ones), the average age of the 3 conservative retirees was 78, whereas the average age of the other 5 liberal retirees was 84.6, suggesting the conservative justices were apt to 'turn over the reigns young' while liberal justices were more keen to hang on for longer. Justice Ginsburg is a good example of a justice who could have retired much sooner in her career during a Democratic presidency - and given her health problems - but chose not to. This article highlights some of these considerations: 
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/27/briefing/supreme-court-justices-breyer-retirement.html.  Justice Breyer has been a federal judge or Supreme Court justice for 41 years, and most certainly knows that even if he were to retire this summer with Biden in the oval office and a Democrat-controlled Senate that his replacement would not change the ideological leaning of the Court, which is currently slanted 6-3 toward the conservative ideology. He has also written a book arguing that the SCOTUS is - and should remain - an apolitical body. All of this points me toward  the notion that there are few incentives for him to retire this summer prior to the mid-term elections.  On the other hand, should Justice Breyer decide to retire and vacate the seat prior to the mid-term elections in 2022, I believe that even if the Senate flips to Republican control that the current Democrat-controlled Senate (which will not adjourn until the end of the current 117th Congress on January 3, 2023)  would push through any Biden nomination made this Summer as political retribution for Republican actions installing Justices Gorsuch and Coney Barrett to the court.  All this leads me to propose that despite the base rate of 66%, there is a high probability that Justice Breyer will NOT vacate the seat. If he does choose to vacate the seat there is as close to certainty as possible that the Senate WILL confirm his replacement prior to January 4, 2023.

Updating to reflect that the question is whether “a … seat” will be vacated, not only Breyer’s seat.  There are 9 justices and death or retirement for other reasons could always happen.  If a vacancy does occur, particularly earlier in the year, the D’s will want to make sure it is filled, which might cause the seemingly fractious party to get behind a consensus replacement.  All of that said, I still think it is unlikely unless someone dies unexpectedly.

Justices are typically loathe to retire without a clear replacement.  With the low approval rating of the President and predicted upcoming turmoil in Congressional elections that may result in power changes and contentious hearings, barring a health crisis, it is unlikely that Justice Breyer will feel comfortable retiring.

According to the Washington Post, twice as many justices (six) retired since 1990 as died in office (three).  Three of the six that retired were 83 or older.  Breyer is the second longest serving justice, and will be 84 this year.  He may have been convinced to retire by watching what happened when Ruth Bader Ginsburg passed away and her seat was filled by a conservative Republican.

There is a chance that a US supreme court seat will be vacated based on their ages and possibly S. Breyer. Unlikely that the Senate will be able to confirm a new Justice by January 2023 should one happen given the political climate and Senator Manchin's stance being more closely aligned with the GOP on several matters. Not sure how he will act if a vacancy occurs. He is trying to secure his next election in his State and given his state is Republican dominant, I feel he is likely to lean more on the right if a Supreme court justice seat is vacated.

I'm fairly confident if an opening on the court happens, there will be a replacement appointed as long as there is sufficient time. It seems there is speculation that Breyer will retire this year [1] which seems plausible. Although I'm not as bullish as the author on the theory, I do think there is a roughly 30% - 40% chance of a planned Breyer retirement this year. Additionally, thanks to the justice age information provided by @pei-w-lee [2], the approximate mortality of the justices can be calculate based on data from the social security administration [3]. Although the justices each seem in good health for their ages, given that each one may retire for other unplanned reasons as well, the combined probability seems like a reasonable estimate for unplanned replacement of at least one justice. I created a quick script to crunch the numbers [4] (which I'll improve upon later) and came up with an approximate 16% chance of an unplanned replacement (with almost half of this mass resting on Breyer alone if he chooses not to retire for political reasons). I think three factors suggest J Breyer will not retire (or die) this year.  First, he began the current term and has said he’s not yet decided.  That suggests he isn’t ready to say he will depart when the session ends in June.  Second, if his retirement is intended to promote the democrats’ chances of confirming a like-minded nominee, there is no guarantee that will happen.  The Senate’s holds a majority only due to the vote of the VP, and as we have seen both Senators Manchin and Sinema have derailed key administration priorities.  Justice Breyer’s replacement therefore would either be dictated by either one of these (or another senator), and the Justice (or the administration) might be worried about the idea of each of fifty senators holding the key to this seat.  Likewise, if a D senator dies or becomes incapacitated after Breyer retires, the Rs would hold the majority.  I didn’t look it up, but my guess is there are many senators that are older or less healthy than he is.  Point 3: Since 1987, 3 Justices died on the bench while 4 retired, which tracks a general near 50/50 trend so it is not like there is any historical tradition that suggests he should leave.

Justices are serving longer (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2017-supreme-court-justice-tenure/)  Looks like Stephen Breyer may be in the homestretch of his tenure. Although progressives have been calling for Breyer to step down (hard lesson from the outcome of RBG refusing to retire during Obama's administration), Breyer hasn't signaled that he plans to retire. The nomination/confirmation process takes an average of 67 days. During the last 2 administrations, nominations took between 60 - 80 days. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/25/how-long-to-confirm-supreme-court-justice.html Justice	Born	Nominated By	In	Leans	Age
Stephen Breyer	1938	Bill Clinton	1994	Liberal	83

Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer says he hasn't decided about retirement, despite pressure from left.(https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/07/15/supreme-court-justice-stephen-breyer-hasnt-decided-retirement/7976546002/)

Since the Supreme Court reached its current size of nine justices in 1869, an average of 89 days has passed between a vacancy appearing on the court and the confirmation of a new justice to fill that spot. (https://usafacts.org/articles/supreme-court-nomination-confirmation-history/)

Breyer has said in multiple interviews that he is not going anywhere.   If he were worried about Republican control he would have left in 2016 or 2020.   At his age, he has an 8% chance of dying within the next year.  Another justice leaving or dying is highly unlikely.

That an "announced retirement effective upon the confirmation of a successor would count as a seat being vacated," is part of the question does complicate things.
A few scenarios:
1) Breyer stays until elections in November to see whether the Senate  flips Republican 
2) Breyer retires hoping that all Democrats vote together on a Biden nominee to replace him. 
3) Breyer stays until or past 2024 as a Senior Justice in the minority.  Breyer is now third in the seniority order and the first liberal to have a shot at influencing a case and any cross-ideological consensus.
I believe that he's more inclined to stick it out regardless of election outcomes. He stated that his health, not politics would drive his decision to retire.  He seems healthy enough as well.

All eyes continue to be on Breyer.  Based on his public comments, he seems to not be interested in retiring nor bending to progressive demands.  His health will be the real question on whether he retires this year.  Especially watch if takes a group of clerks over the summer, otherwise he is retiring after the Fall session.  He might announce a retirement after the Spring session as well.  However, I believe it is highly unlikely that he retires this year.  Breyer has been on the Court long enough to know that Supreme Court confirmations in elections years are an extremely messy affair.

Death is the most likely reason for a vacancy I believe because there really is only one Justice (Breyer) that would be in a position to retire.  He has been ADAMANT that he won't retire; he says it in books, interviews and in private.  So I started with an 82% chance there would be no change, (the 18% is the chance of death) but then I ultimately dropped it 5% for the possibility that the pressure campaign against him succeeds and he relents.   The confirmation rate of the last 15 candidate Justices is 80%.  But due to the nature of the Red/Blue senator divide and the likelihood the senate flips in 2022, I would lower the 80% estimate because of Mitch McConnell's previous tricks of denying hearings for Garland.  So assuming McConnell would be the majority leader in 2022, I think he'd have no qualms having an empty seat for over a year.  Thus I moved the likelihood of confirmation under a Republican majority to 57%.  57% of 23 (the remaining piece of the pie after the 77% "No) is 13%.

For this forecast I will solely look at Justice Breyer who at age 83 is by far the oldest current US Supreme Court Justice. If Breyer leaves the Supreme Court in 2022 it will be either due to (1) Death, (2) Retirement or (3) Illness (1) Death -
At age 83, Breyer has a 8% chance of dying -
https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html (2) Retirement
I think there is a very good chance (approx 60%) of Breyer announcing his retirement this year. Firstly, due to his age and secondly as a liberal judge it would make perfect sense for him to retire now while Democrats control both the White House and the Senate thereby ensuring (If Senators Manchin and Sinema agree with Biden's nominee) he will be replaced by another liberal Supreme Court Justice. If he doesn't retire in 2022 the Republicans could potentially take control of the Senate in the 2022 Mid Terms meaning he would have to wait at least 2 years for the Democrats to potentially retake the Senate and keep the Presidency in the 2024 Senate and Presidential Elections. (3) Illness
He seems healthy so I consider it a small chance (e.g. 5%) that he has to leave the Supreme Court due to illness.  Breyer Leaves the US Supreme Court in 2022 = 73% = Death + Retirement + Illness Supreme Court Justices announce their retirement in the runup to their recess from June - October so if Breyer hasn't announced his retirement before July I will assume that he isn't retiring in 2022 and I will adjust my forecast. For me the big unknown question at the moment is that if Breyer does retire in 2022 if Senators Manchin and Sinema will vote for Biden's nominee given both have stymied President Biden before. Yes Vacancy But No Replacement Before 4/1/2023  = 7% = 73% * .1
No Vacancy Before 4/1/2023 = 27%

Darn, got the first and second answers the wrong way around before.... Based on the last 10 retirements, a SC Justice retires about once every 3 years. This suggests a base rate of a little under 1/3 (some years may have multiple retirements). There has been speculation that Breyer may retire for strategic partisan purposes, but I see little evidence to think he will, both in the recent history of retirements and in public statements that Breyer has made. (In fact he wrote a book recently about the importance of keeping the Court pure of politics.) However, Breyer is already 3 years past the average retirement age of the last 10 Justices to retire. The combination of Breyer's age and the ages of the 10 most recent retirees suggest about a 1/3 chance of *Breyer* retiring. There is also, of course, a small but significant (say 12%) chance that a vacancy comes from someone else, especially because of COVID. This amounts to about a 40-45% chance of a vacancy. Conditional on the Democrats still holding at least 50 Senate seats and the vacancy coming by the end of August, say, I think it is very likely they confirm a replacement by Jan 3. If the vacancy comes later, it might be a coin flip on average.

Adjusting down bucket 2, because for it to happen it has to be that someone dies in December AND no other retirements/deaths have taken place, rather than just absolute odds that someone dies in December.

There are two main ways for a vacancy on the US Supreme court to occur: death or retirement. It's possible for a justice to be impeached and removed, but that seems highly unlikely. Calculating the probability of death can be done using the social security website, which has the probability of death in the next year by age and gender: https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html Clarence Thomas	Age: 73 yr 6 mo: 3%
Stephen Breyer	Age: 83 yr 5 mo:  7.6% 
John G. Roberts	Age: 66 yr 11 mo: 1.7% 
Samuel A. Alito, Jr. Age: 71 yr 9 mo: 2.4%
Sonia Sotomayor	Age: 67 yr 6 mo: 1.1%
Elena Kagan	Age: 61 yr 8 mo : 0.7%
Neil McGill Gorsuch Age: 54 yr 4 mo: 0.7% 
Brett Michael Kavanaugh Age: 56 yr 11 mo: 0.8%
Amy Coney Barrett Age: 49 yr 11 mo: 0.2% In total, about an 18% chance of a supreme court justice dying in the next year. There is reason to think the true probability is lower (these are wealthy individuals with access to high quality health care). So let's say around 15%.  The other way a justice can create a vacancy is by retiring. It would be highly unlikely for any of the conservative justices to retire (only Thomas is old) and since Joe Biden is president they would be replaced by a liberal justice. Therefore, only Breyer, Sotomayor, or Kagan may retire. The final two are pretty young <70 so it's very unlikely. Breyer is more complicated. Given the fact that RBG recently was in a parallel situation, decided not to retire, and was then replaced by a conservative justice suggests it is likely he will retire. This is his best chance as after this upcoming election the Democrats could well lose control of the Senate. But, Joe Biden's presidency lasts three more years, so it's very possible he waits it out another year or two. Or it's possible he does the same thing as RBG. It's tough to forecast and Breyer hasn't given many signals. I'll say there is a 30% chance he'll retire this year.  This gives us a 45% chance of a vacancy and a 55% chance of no vacancy. If there is a vacancy, I'm confident Democrats would move as fast as possible to replace the justice because the Senate majority is quite likely not going to remain. If the vacancy occurs after the midterm elections that may make it tricky navigating, or they may just push through with a lame-duck Senate anyway.

Bucket two is the odds that someone dies in like late November/December specifically, so very low. Otherwise this is mainly a Breyer retire market Breyer has indicated 1) he affirmatively does *not* want to die on the court and 2) he does not want his judicial legacy overturned by his successor. His very last chance to guarantee these things is to retire this summer. So I put high probability on him retiring. Kennedy did the same in 2018
Yes and yes up 10% to be ahead of the consensus.

For now this is my forecast, with clarification pending with regard to technicalities of the question. What if, though, Thomas or Sonia or Breyer get tired of this remote style of court caused by COVID. Subconsciously this may trigger a Justice to call it quits. But this is probably very unlikely. I started with 66% no and it could be as easily a 70 to 90% no. However, I bend toward the crowd median which is supported by reasonable scenarios that could happen this term or next term.

Breyer probably has only a 1 in 4 or 1 in 5 change of deciding to retire as a political move but the odds that he dies or resigns over health - or that any Justices die - or a liberal Justice resigns over health - are moderate. A Justice would have to die literally in the last week before Christmas for Dems to fail to confirm a replacement.

It seems possible that Breyer will retire before the next election (November 2024), but he hasn't indicated that he is in a rush to retire (which excludes retiring before the 2022 midterms) and seems to be relatively healthy. I'm not aware of any other judges on the SCOTUS that are likely to retire/die.
